newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: South Korean oil products flood Asia.
newsitem.headline: South Korean oil products flood Asia.

text.p: South Korean refiners are flooding Asia with oil products following a flurry of refinery expansions last year and a slowdown in domestic consumption, industry analysts said on Tuesday.

South Korea's petroleum products exports jumped 91 percent to 55.6 million barrels in the first quarter of 1997 against 29.1 million a year before, according to the Ministry of Trade, Industry and Energy.
Analysts said refiners were likely to maintain high double-digit growth for the rest of this year with domestic demand expected to remain low.
"The main reason behind the rise is a refining capacity increase and slower domestic demand," said George Goundry, an energy analyst at HG Asia.
He forecast exports growth of 50-90 percent for the first half and 30-50 percent for the second half.
Analysts said refiners had no choice but to dump products onto the Asian market.
South Korea's refining capacity rose to 2.44 million barrels per day (bpd) by the end of 1996, from 1.82 million at the end of 1995.
Last year, Hyundai Oil Refinery Co added 200,000-bpd of refining capacity, Yukong Ltd 200,000 bpd and LG-Caltex Oil Corp 220,000 bpd.

Yukong, the nation's largest oil refiner with a 810,000-bpd capacity, expanded its exports by 355 percent to 9.37 million barrels in the first two months from 2.06 million a year ago, according to data provided by the state-run Korea Petroleum Development Corp (PEDCO).
LG-Caltex raised it by 278 percent to 4.54 million barrels and Hyundai by 729 percent to 5.10 million.
"With local consumption shrinking, refiners are more pressured to sell products abroad," said Kim Sang-bae, an energy analyst at Ssangyong Investment Securities.
Domestic demand slipped 0.4 percent to 204.0 million barrels in the first quarter of 1997 from 204.8 million a year earlier. In comparison, consumption rose 9.6 percent in the first quarter of 1996.
The Energy Ministry cited slower industrial growth, an active energy conservation campaign and higher demand for liquefied natural gas as the prime reasons for the slide in domestic demand.
Analysts said the government was also encouraging oil products exports to help improve the ballooning current account deficit.
They said the Korean refiners were betting on China and Japan to consume much of their surplus this year, while casting around for new markets in Southeast Asia.
China, South Korea's biggest export market, purchased 13.04 million barrels of oil products from South Korea in the first two months of this year against 3.18 million a year ago, according to PEDCO.
Japan was the second largest buyer, with Hong Kong tailing behind.
